subject: Re: [junit] Junit output on assertEquals
msgSnippet: I find the new way of doing the difference better than displaying the whole toString()., Ofthen the toString() is way to large, for objects including other
messageBody:
I find the new way of doing the difference better than displaying the whole
toString()., Ofthen the toString() is way to large, for objects including other objects, which
may include its toString(). But this implementation could be way much better, for example
it could just find the difference and back 15 chars before and after, or do some syntax
parsing to find a good place.

It seems that many people want an option to disable the difference, set the number of
characters before and after and perhaps which tokens it should find before and after
the difference.

I posted a patch on th junit-devel list in december, but havent heard any reactions on it.
Maybe I could extend my path by including the options above and then perhaps it may
be accepted or at least adopted... This bug should be fixed becaus it is annoying to
get resluts like this :
assertEquals( Float.toString( 0.124235f), Float.toString( 0.124435f ) );
// old result - which one of the 2's is wrong?
expected:<...2...> but was:<...4...>
// with patch:
expected:<0.124235> but was:<0.124435>

//Erik

( my patch suggestion is up on the juni sourceforge patch page)
----- Original Message -----
From: <justin.thomas@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, January 30, 2003 11:10 PM
Subject: [junit] Junit output on assertEquals


> Hi,
>
> When my test fails I get a truncated difference of the actual
> against expected. This is really annoying as more often than not
> it's too difficult to tell which part the difference comes from.
>
> For example this test fails with the following output:
>
> [junit] Convert JDN 10000: expected:<...1> but was:<...2>
> [junit] junit.framework.ComparisonFailure: Convert JDN 10000:
> expected:<...1> but was:<...2>
>
> [junit] TEST com.calendar.tests.gregorianTest FAILED
>
> The bit in angle brackets is useless to me what it should say is
> expected:<"-4685/4/12"> but was:<"-4685/4/11">. Can anyone tell me
> how to stop the output being truncated like this?
>
> Thanks
>
>
